name: Sagittarius A*
description: Sagittarius A* (pronounced 'Sagittarius A-star') is the supermassive black hole at the center of our Milky Way galaxy. It has a mass of about 4 million times that of our Sun.
funFacts: Stars orbit Sagittarius A* at speeds over 8,000 km/s.
The Event Horizon Telescope imaged it in 2022.
The black hole is remarkably quiet despite its size.
It is surrounded by a cluster of massive young stars.
imageKeyword: sagittarius a star black hole milky way

name: M87* (P≈çwehi)
description: M87* was the first black hole to be directly imaged by the Event Horizon Telescope in 2019. It is a supermassive black hole at the center of the giant elliptical galaxy Messier 87.
funFacts: First black hole ever directly imaged (2019).
Its mass is 6.5 billion times that of our Sun.
The event horizon is larger than our solar system.
It produces a powerful jet of plasma 5,000 light-years long.

name: Cygnus X-1
description: Cygnus X-1 was the first widely accepted black hole candidate. It is a stellar-mass black hole in a binary system with a blue supergiant star.
funFacts: Subject of a famous bet between Stephen Hawking and Kip Thorne.
It pulls material from its companion star, creating an accretion disk.
The black hole completes one orbit every 5.6 days.
It was one of the strongest X-ray sources discovered early on.

name: GRS 1915+105
description: GRS 1915+105 is a stellar black hole known for its extremely rapid and complex X-ray variability. It was the first known galactic source to produce superluminal jets.
funFacts: Spins at nearly 1,150 rotations per second.
Produces jets that appear to move faster than light.
Has the most variable X-ray output of any known source.
The companion star is being cannibalized by the black hole.

name: TON 618
description: TON 618 hosts one of the most massive known black holes, with an estimated mass of 66 billion solar masses. It powers an extremely luminous quasar.
funFacts: One of the most massive black holes ever discovered.
The event horizon could encompass our entire solar system.
The quasar shines with the light of 140 trillion suns.
Located at the edge of the observable universe.
